diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect kidneys (proteinuria), the brain (delirium), and the heart (acute pericarditis and pericardial effusion).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily a joint disorder, it can lead to systemic complications including pericarditis and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This condition features signs of several autoimmune diseases and can present with pericarditis, renal involvement (proteinuria), and neurologic symptoms (delirium).

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: A multisystem autoimmune disease that can cause pericarditis and kidney involvement (manifesting as proteinuria). Neurological involvement could explain delirium.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: An infection of the heart's inner lining, which can lead to pericardial effusion, and kidney damage (proteinuria). It can also cause systemic symptoms including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Uremic Pericarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Seen in advanced kidney disease, resulting in the accumulation of uremic toxins, which can lead to pericarditis. Proteinuria is a common feature of chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Several viruses can cause pericarditis and pericardial effusion, with potential systemic effects that could contribute to delirium. Secondary kidney damage might manifest as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: A systemic infectious disease that can lead to pericarditis and pericardial effusion. Kidney involvement can cause proteinuria, and CNS involvement could explain delirium.

diagnoses.name: Cancer with Pericardial and Renal Involvement
diagnoses.rationale: Certain cancers can metastasize to the pericardium and kidneys, leading to pericarditis, pericardial effusion, and proteinuria. Delirium can be a secondary effect.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the kidneys (proteinuria), CKD can lead to complications including uremic pericarditis. Delirium may occur due to metabolic imbalances.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary renal involvement
Primary angiitis of the central nervous system

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing an increased risk of blood clots (thromboembolic disease) and could potentially explain thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Can lead to thrombocytopenia due to splenic sequestration of platelets, can also cause gastroesophageal reflux due to increased abdominal pressure.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect blood cell production in the bone marrow, potentially causing both thrombocytopenia and thromboembolic events.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause thrombocytopenia and is associated with an increased risk of thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.description: Various cancers, especially pancreatic cancer, can cause thrombocytopenia and increase the risk of thromboembolic events. Gastrointestinal cancers can also be associated with gastroesophageal reflux symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Can potentially cause thrombocytopenia, gastroesophageal reflux, and can be associated with a higher risk of developing Otitis externa due to general body edema and fluid accumulation.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: Chronic heart failure can cause congestion and increase the risk of thromboembolic disease. It may also contribute to gastroesophageal reflux.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to thrombocytopenia. Though less directly related, patients might experience symptoms like gastroesophageal reflux and congestion.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to thrombosis and might explain thrombocytopenia. Other symptoms can align with the vascular and systemic impact of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) with Secondary Complications
diagnoses.description: While GERD primarily explains the gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, in severe cases, it may coexist with other systemic illnesses that could explain the full symptom profile.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Leukoplakia, particularly oral hairy leukoplakia, can be a manifestation of HIV/AIDS. This condition can also lead to lymph node enlargement (lymphadenitis) due to the body's immune response. Individuals with advanced HIV/AIDS may experience various infections and conditions that could contribute to difficulty focusing vision, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Diabetes can lead to a variety of complications that could hypothetically explain these symptoms. Atherosclerosis is a common complication of long-standing or poorly controlled diabetes, and diabetes can also affect vision (though typically through retinopathy rather than difficulty focusing as a primary symptom). Constipation can be a feature of diabetic autonomic neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.reasoning: Lupus can cause a wide array of symptoms throughout the body including lymphadenitis. It can affect various organs including the skin (possibly contributing to leukoplakia-like lesions), blood vessels (contributing to atherosclerosis), and even the nervous system, possibly affecting vision. Lupus can also impact gastrointestinal transit, leading to constipation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This autoimmune disease primarily affects the body’s moisture-producing glands. Dry eyes can lead to difficulty focusing vision. Secondary Sjögren’s syndrome can be associated with other autoimmune conditions like lupus, which might explain some of the other symptoms including lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.reasoning: Secondary syphilis can cause lymphadenopathy (lymphadenitis), mucous membrane lesions (which could be confused with leukoplakia), and has cardiovascular implications that could relate to atherosclerosis. Neurosyphilis can impact vision and potentially cause constipation due to autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: A deficiency in vitamin B12 can lead to neurological changes affecting vision and gastrointestinal motility, potentially leading to constipation. It can also indirectly contribute to atherosclerosis via elevated homocysteine levels. Though less directly related, vitamin deficiencies could impact immune function and possibly contribute to lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.reasoning: This chronic inflammatory condition affects the skin and mucous membranes, which could explain leukoplakia-like lesions in the mouth. Though less directly related to the other symptoms, systemic involvement can include various organ systems, potentially linking to broader symptomatology.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: CKD can cause a range of systemic symptoms including changes in calcium and phosphate balance that contribute to vascular health issues (and potentially atherosclerosis). It can also cause disturbances in electrolyte and fluid balance, leading to constipation. Uremia associated with CKD can impact numerous body systems, potentially affecting vision and causing a generalized immune response leading to lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition represents a group of rare diseases characterized by autoimmune activity against more than one endocrine organ, but non-endocrine organs can be affected as well. It can lead to a constellation of symptoms depending on the organs involved. For instance, autoimmune thyroid disease could impact cholesterol levels (relevant to atherosclerosis) and gastrointestinal motility (leading to constipation), and autoimmune destruction of moisture-producing glands could impair vision.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare disorder causes blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. It can lead to symptoms including mouth sores that could be mistaken for leukoplakia, eye inflammation affecting vision, and vascular issues possibly explaining atherosclerosis. Bowel involvement can lead to gastrointestinal symptoms including constipation.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can cause hypertension, fluid retention leading to swelling (which could contribute to angioedema), and electrolyte imbalances that might manifest as episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that occurs when the body does not have enough iron, leading to fatigue, weakness, and can also contribute to restless legs syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, potentially leading to episodic weakness, among various other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease that occurs when a substance called amyloid builds up in your organs. Amyloid deposits can lead to varying symptoms including angioedema, episodic weakness, and kidney issues affecting blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.description: A progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement. Symptoms can include tremors, stiffness, and in later stages, postural instability. It is also associated with restless legs syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to the nerves located outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causing weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet. It may also contribute to restless legs syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Primary Aldosteronism (Conn's Syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A type of hormonal disorder that leads to high blood pressure due to overproduction of the hormone aldosterone by the adrenal glands. It may be associated with episodic muscle weakness due to potassium depletion.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). While primarily known for its impact on blood sugar levels and insulin function, it can lead to neuropathy, which might exacerbate restless legs syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing episodes of severe swelling in various parts of the body, including the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway. It may not directly link to the other symptoms but should be considered given the presence of angioedema.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the eyes, mouth, skin, and genitals. Symptoms often include mouth ulcers, genital ulcers, eye inflammation, and skin issues.

diagnoses.name: Herpes simplex
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that leads to the formation of sores and ulcers. It can cause eye problems, especially when the herpes simplex virus affects the eye.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
diagnoses.description: A common viral infection that can cause warts on different parts of the body, including the genitals and skin. Certain strains can lead to more serious conditions.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Symptoms include skin rash, blisters, and the detachment of the upper surface of the skin.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms range widely and can include skin lesions.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the glands that produce tears and saliva, leading to dry eyes and mouth. It can also cause dysfunction in other organs, including the skin and digestive system.

diagnoses.name: Squamous cell carcinoma
diagnoses.description: A common form of skin cancer that may present with lesions or ulcers on the skin. People with long-standing or severe HPV infections have an increased risk of developing this cancer.

diagnoses.name: Mucous membrane pemphigoid
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that causes blistering lesions on mucous membranes such as the mouth, eyes, throat, and genitals, potentially leading to dysphagia and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Reactive arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body, manifesting as conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis. Skin manifestations can include ulcers and lesions.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that weakens the immune system, leading to a wide range of symptoms and opportunistic infections. Symptoms can include mouth ulcers, skin rashes, and a variety of other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses: Eating Disorders (e.g., Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa)
Vitamin Deficiency – Difficulty in focusing, easy bruising, and digestive issues could be indicative of a deficiency in essential vitamins, such as vitamin B12, vitamin C, or vitamin D.
Chronic Sinusitis – Persistent sinusitis could explain the difficulty focusing due to pressure or pain, and it can overlap with gastroesophageal symptoms.
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) – Directly corresponds to symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux and can contribute to dyspepsia; might also exacerbate sinusitis symptoms.

Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome – This condition involves the formation of one or more tumors in the pancreas or the upper part of the small intestine (duodenum) that secrete excess levels of gastrin, leading to increased stomach acid, severe peptic ulcers, reflux, and associated symptoms.
Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes – A group of disorders that affect connective tissues and can lead to easy bruising and digestive issues, among other symptoms.
Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) – A disorder that can cause easy bruising due to a low platelet count, and might also affect other areas of health, including gastrointestinal tract functioning.

Coeliac Disease – An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms like dyspepsia, and could contribute to other symptoms through malabsorption.
Functional Dyspepsia – Often an exclusion diagnosis when symptoms of dyspepsia occur without a clear organic cause. This could coexist with GERD and other symptoms.
Helicobacter Pylori Infection – A bacterial infection that can cause peptic ulcers and lead to symptoms of dyspepsia and reflux. It could indirectly affect other symptoms.

Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) – NAFLD can lead to gastrointestinal symptoms, impact absorption and metabolism of nutrients, thus potentially leading to symptoms like easy bruising and possibly affecting vision indirectly through associated vitamin deficiencies.
Gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., Crohn's disease, Irritable bowel syndrome)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Infectious diseases (severe cases can cause similar symptoms)
Urinary tract infection (UTI) leading to sepsis

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, confusion, trouble seeing, walking, severe headache, and more, corresponding to the symptoms described.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It can cause an array of symptoms including vision loss, pain, fatigue, and impaired coordination. The symptoms may vary widely and include muscular weakness and difficulty with coordination and balance.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a significant source of both headache and neurological deficits. Migraine attacks can cause significant pain for hours to days and be so severe that the pain is disabling. Warning signs can include disturbances in vision, sensitivity to light and sound, and sometimes speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can press on nerve cells in the brain. Symptoms depend on the location and size of the tumor but can include headache, nausea, vomiting, weakness on one side of the body, changes in mood, personality or behavior, difficulty with speech, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or trauma. The symptoms can resemble those of more common conditions, like stroke, and include severe headaches, fever, nausea, vomiting, neurological deficits, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding the brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck. It can also lead to neurological issues, including confusion and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: Myasthenia gravis is characterized by weakness and rapid fatigue of any of the muscles under your voluntary control. It's caused by a breakdown in the normal communication between nerves and muscles. There can be difficulty in speaking (dysarthria), and facial paralysis, closely mimicking some of the symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a transient ischemic attack (TIA) produces similar symptoms to a stroke, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. Often, it's a warning sign of a future stroke. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, confusion, and difficulty with speech or vision.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and even paralysis. Symptoms can begin with weakness and tingling in your extremities and in severe cases, the person could become almost completely paralyzed.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: This is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, the area between the brain and the tissues that cover it. The primary symptom is a sudden, severe headache often described as the worst headache ever experienced. It can also cause confusion, seizures, and weakness in specific parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is accompanied by visual disturbances such as scintillations and may also include symptoms like aphasia, tinnitus, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include headache, aphasia, and sometimes tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke, including aphasia and headache, but typically lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. It can present with headache, vomiting, aphasia, and sometimes tinnitus depending on its location in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include vomiting, headaches, and in severe cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: This occurs when a diseased blood vessel within the brain bursts, allowing blood to leak inside the brain. Symptoms may include headache, vomiting, and in severe cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In some cases, it can cause tinnitus, though typically not associated with aphasia or scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Lobe Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A chronic neurological condition characterized by recurrent, unprovoked seizures originating from the temporal lobe of the brain. It can sometimes present with aphasia and auditory phenomena similar to tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumor that develops on the main nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain. Symptoms may include tinnitus, as well as balance problems and hearing loss, but typically not headache, aphasia, or scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Posterior Circulation Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurring in the back part of the brain, affecting the cerebellum, brainstem, or occipital lobes. It can present with a variety of symptoms, including headache, tinnitus, and, in some cases, aphasia and visual disturbances like scintillation.

diagnoses: Chronic Kidney Disease (secondary to systemic conditions)
Schizophrenia (psychosis with no apparent physical cause)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Viral Infections (e.g., Human Immunodeficiency Virus, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
